and here's what it produced:

Quote

In Desmos, you can define a piecewise function to map different ranges of input values to different output values. The syntax for a piecewise function in Desmos is:

f(x) = \begin{cases} y_1 & x \leq x_1 \ y_2 & x_1 < x \leq x_2 \ \vdots \ y_n & x_n < x \end{cases}

To use this syntax for your specific function, you could write:

f(x) = \begin{cases} 0 & x \leq 99 \ 1 & 100 \leq x \leq 599 \ 2 & 600 \leq x \leq 1599 \ 3 & 1600 \leq x \leq 3099 \ 4 & 3100 \leq x \leq 5099 \ \end{cases}

This piecewise function will return the appropriate value of Y based on the input value of X.

I have no knowledge to be able to comment on the correctness or otherwise of this answer.   I merely present what the bot said.

I then asked it a follow-on question,

Quote

There is a pattern. The step to each level is 500 more points than the previous step, which in principle could continue on to infinity. Is there a way to write this in Desmos so that it could return Y values for arbitrarily large values of X?

...and here's what it said:

Quote

Yes, you can use the floor function and integer division to write a formula that returns Y values for arbitrarily large values of X.

Here's an example formula you can use:

f(x) = \left\lfloor \frac{x}{500} \right\rfloor

This formula takes the input value of x, divides it by 500 using integer division (which truncates any decimal values), and then uses the floor function to round down to the nearest integer. This integer represents the number of times x has increased by 500 over the starting value of 0.

For example, if x = 750, the formula calculates:

f(750) = \left\lfloor \frac{750}{500} \right\rfloor = \left\lfloor 1.5 \right\rfloor = 1

So the formula returns a Y value of 1 for this input value of X. Similarly, if x = 1600, the formula calculates:

f(1600) = \left\lfloor \frac{1600}{500} \right\rfloor = \left\lfloor 3.2 \right\rfloor = 3

So the formula returns a Y value of 3 for this input value of X.

This formula will work for any input value of X, no matter how large it is, as long as it is an integer.

Huh.  
 

Well, I welcome our robot overlords then.
